thread.title: Teenage girl accused of killing seven-year-old stab victim Katie Rough denies murder - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Teenage girl accused of killing seven-year-old stab victim Katie Rough denies murder - Mirror Online

author: Richard Wheatstone
title: Teenage girl accused of killing seven-year-old stab victim Katie Rough denies murder - Mirror Online
text:
The teenager denied murder during a short court appearance (Photo: London News Pictures Ltd) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A teenage girl accused of killing seven-year-old schoolgirl Katie Rough has denied her murder. 
Katie was found with severe lacerations to her neck and chest on a playing field near her home in York and died later in hospital on January 9. 
The teenager was arrested after Katie was found injured and charged with murder and possession of an offensive weapon, a knife. 
The 15-year-old - who cannot be named for legal reasons - pleaded not guilty during a short hearing at Leeds Crown Court. 
She will now face trial in July. Katie Rough died after suffering severe lacerations to her neck on January 9 (Photo: PA) The 15-year-old girl appeared at Leeds Crown Court (Photo: London News Pictures Ltd) 
On Monday, hundreds of mourners donned rainbow-coloured accessories to celebrate Katie's life at her funeral at York Minster. 
Around 400 people packed into the cathedral for a service led by the Archbishop of York, Dr John Sentamu. 
Dr Sentamu told the congregation that he sat with Katie's coffin overnight after realising she would be alone following a family service at his Bishopthorpe Palace residence. 
Mourners wore bright scarves and ties and a number of young children wore rainbow-coloured hair bows after they were asked by Katie's parents to dress formally but with a colourful twist. 
A number of family members gave tearful Bible readings and Katie's uncle, Steven Rough, paid tribute to his niece. The coffin of seven-year-old Katie Rough leaves York Minster following a funeral service (Photo: PA) Archbishop of York Dr John Sentamu leads the family into York Minster (Photo: PA) 
He said: "We should focus on how happy she made us when she was in our lives." 
Mr Rough described "daddy's girl" Katie's love of the outdoors and reading, particularly poetry and Dr Seuss, and talked about her family's memories. 
He said: "Her family were her world." Like us on Facebook
